stream_context.summary: Kaze and Zeina work on the Course 11 oil-rig level, finishing the breakable-glass gag, writing NPC dialogue, designing a Wiggler foreman, and planning a hidden Wing Cap while previewing Kaze’s separate "Only Up 64" ROM hack.

development_findings.summary: Course 11 is in active production; once finished only four more levels remain before the hack is content-complete.
development_findings.quote: How many levels until complete? Four after this.

development_findings.summary: Mission 1 revolves around ‘trolling’ Bowser’s workers; Kaze finalised four gags (glass-carrying Koopas, lunch Koopa, crane Koopa, tool-box Koopa) and scrapped an oil-barrel slip gag for being too cryptic.
development_findings.quote: I think kicking the oil barrel is not intuitive … I think oil guy is gone.

development_findings.summary: Glass mechanic: chosen approach is two pre-cut panes that fall with hard-coded motion; no real physics, minimising work and CPU/GPU load.
development_findings.quote: We’re just going to fake it so we don’t actually have to write a physics simulation.

development_findings.summary: Secret Wing Cap will be optional, placed on a high crane rope; soft invisible walls will keep players out of non-rendered areas.
development_findings.quote: Alright, we’re just gonna add a wing cap, just for the fun of it … the only invisible wall we need is here.

development_findings.summary: Kaze reused code from a breakable door to speed up the glass interaction implementation.
development_findings.quote: So right now I’m looking for the code for like a breakable door I made so we can just copy paste that.

development_findings.summary: Polygon budget constraints forced redesign of the Wiggler NPC; helmets on every segment were removed and feet simplified, reducing the model to ~670 tris.
development_findings.quote: 240 polygons is just the hats … can’t waste my polygon budget like that.

development_findings.summary: Engine runs at 60 FPS on real N64 hardware, aided by new sine/cosine approximations and a preference for static over dynamic collision.
development_findings.quote: We also have new sine approximations … they’re going to be so much better now.

development_findings.summary: Fast iteration: full ROM recompiles take only seconds on Kaze’s setup, allowing live tweaking during stream.
Safe-state detection for "Only Up 64" uses EEPROM desync checks; demonstrates Kaze’s anti-cheat thinking for future projects.
development_findings.quote: I detect whether the EPROM desyncs from the memory state.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is remote staff for Gears for Breakfast, focusing on optimisation; he values work-from-home and avoids physical offices.
context_findings.quote: Working at Gears is super chill … We all work from home. I don’t want to work in a physical building.

context_findings.summary: He receives free hardware from Chinese manufacturers in exchange for testing/reviews, supplementing limited finances while house-hunting.
context_findings.quote: I often get emails from Chinese manufacturers … I got a monitor, a capture card … I’m trying to buy a house right now, I need those $20.

context_findings.summary: Strong design philosophy: dislikes hand-holding and 2D platformers; champions control-stick and even proposes ‘controller + mouse’ hybrids for precision.
context_findings.quote: I can’t even stand Celeste … Controller plus mouse is the future.

context_findings.summary: Personal dynamic: Zeina vetoes Kaze’s plan to shave his head; shows lighthearted interplay between marriage and dev life.
context_findings.quote: I was just gonna cut it off, but she won’t let me … Woman moment.

biobak.summary: Absent this stream; team jokes about assigning him the comedic ‘Andrew Tate OST’ theme song.
biobak.quote: What if we just start calling this the Biobak theme song … Biobak would hate that.

badub.summary: Provided an unfinished draft of the oil-rig level soundtrack; Kaze is pleased with the direction.
badub.quote: Oh yeah, you guys haven’t heard it yet but Badub made a soundtrack for this level … I like a lot of the ideas.

zeina.summary: Created baby-penguin walk, waddle, dive, get-up and idle animations; fixed model issues (neck hole) and will animate the complex Wiggler next.
zeina.quote: All the animations are done except for the penguin’s idle … He’s gonna be the most difficult one to animate yet.

zeina.summary: Assists modelling decisions (e.g., boot size, helmet scaling) and occasionally moderates chat.

key_stories.title: From Physics to Fakery
key_stories.summary: Kaze wanted a dramatic glass-shatter when Mario dives into the pane carried by Koopas. Full physics or many fragments proved too work-intensive, so he settled on two pre-cut pieces with scripted motion.
key_stories.challenge: Achieve convincing glass break within N64 limits.
key_stories.process: Debated particle shards, multi-piece models, Blender physics; ultimately cut model into two pieces and hard-coded a fall-and-spin path.
key_stories.outcome: Effect looks believable, keeps performance high, and first mission logic is now functional.
key_stories.key_quote: We’re just gonna fake it so we don’t actually have to write a physics simulation.

key_stories.title: The Scrapped Oil Barrel Gag
key_stories.summary: An idea where Mario kicks a leaking oil drum to make a worker slip was removed mid-stream.
key_stories.challenge: Gag felt unintuitive and not funny enough.
key_stories.process: Kaze weighed player discoverability and comedic payoff, discussed alternatives, then deleted the object.
key_stories.outcome: Mission now uses only four trolls, streamlining design.
key_stories.key_quote: I think kicking the oil barrel is not intuitive … I want something else or just nothing.

key_stories.title: Designing the Wiggler Foreman
key_stories.summary: A Wiggler oversees the oil-rig crew and reacts to each prank, but modelling him within hardware limits proved tricky.
key_stories.challenge: Original concept with helmets on every segment exceeded polygon budget.
key_stories.process: Iterative reduction—removed helmet interiors, shrank foot detail, settled on ~670 tris.
key_stories.outcome: Model approved; Zeina to animate; Wiggler will run off angrily and spawn the star.
key_stories.key_quote: 240 polygons is just the hats … can’t waste my polygon budget like that.

open_questions.topic: Final behaviour and dialogue of the Wiggler foreman
open_questions.context: Model exists but AI path, anger stages, and star-spawn cut-scene are only roughly outlined.
questions: How will his anger escalate mechanically?
Will he track how many trolls the player completes?
What comedic tone do you want for his final monologue?

open_questions.context: Kaze stated only four courses remain after Course 11 but gave no detail.
questions: What are the themes and key mechanics of the last four courses?
Which ones are complete in design vs. production?
What new technical hurdles do they present?

open_questions.context: Kaze touted faster trigonometry functions but didn’t explain math or gains.
questions: What specific approximation method are you using?
How much performance was recovered on real hardware?
Any visual side-effects or precision trade-offs?

open_questions.topic: Team pipeline for models and animations
open_questions.context: Zeina works in Blender; Kaze handles export/engine integration, but details were sparse.
questions: What file formats and tools bridge Blender to the custom engine?
How do you handle version control remotely?

open_questions.topic: Overlap with Gears for Breakfast day-job
open_questions.context: Kaze is optimising a commercial title while hacking in spare time.
questions: How do you manage time and avoid burnout?
Does professional engine work feed back into ROM-hack tech?
Any NDA constraints limiting community transparency?

open_questions.context: Nintendo ROM-hacks sit in a grey area; nothing was discussed.
questions: Are there contingency plans if Nintendo issues takedown notices?
Will ‘Return to Yoshi’s Island’ be distributed as a patch?
How is the team preparing for potential legal pushback?
